description: Sir Christopher Wren's riverside masterpiece in Greenwich, built as the Royal Hospital for Seamen and begun in 1696.

events.name: Grand Square pop-up talk
events.notes: Bookable in person on the day.

events.name: King William Courtyard pop-up talk
events.notes: Bookable in person on the day. We regret there is no step-free access for this talk.

events.name: Jacobean Undercroft visit
events.notes: Booking essential, in person on the day. The Undercroft is reached by a flight of steps: we regret there is no step-free access for this talk. We request that all participants wear a face covering unless exempt.

events.name: Tour of the Chapel
events.notes: Bookable in-person on the day. The Chapel was built by English architect Thomas Ripley (1682-1758) following designs by Sir Christopher Wren, for the use of the staff and pensioners of the Royal Hospital for Seamen. In 1779 the Chapel was gutted by fire: its interior was rebuilt in a neo-classical style by James ‘Athenian’ Stuart (1713-1788). It features a large altarpiece painting by the American artist Benjamin West (1738-1820).

factsheet.heading: Admiral’s House
paragraphs: Sunday 5 September, 10.00-17.00, drop-in.

One of the oldest surviving parts of the site, Admiral’s House, overlooking the Thames, was once the residence of the Governor of the Royal Hospital for Seamen. Originally designed by John Webb for Charles II as part of a plan to create a royal palace to rival Versailles. A rare chance to view this elegant space.
We request that visitors to Admiral's House wear a face covering unless exempt.

factsheet.heading: Grand Square
paragraphs: Saturday 4 and Sunday 5 September, 10.30-15.30, pop-up talks

The Grand Square of the Old Royal Naval College lies at the heart of one of the most spectacular architectural complexes in Europe.  These talks will explore the histories behind the sweeping vistas on view.
The Grand Square talk will last approximately 15 minutes and will be repeated on the half hour from 10.30 to 15.30.

factsheet.heading: King William Courtyard
paragraphs: Saturday 4 and Sunday 5 September, 11.00-16.00, pop-up talks

Hawksmoor’s work in the King William Courtyard, with its massive scale and sculptural enrichment, is a quintessential example of English Baroque architecture.  The Courtyard is overlooked by the Nelson Pediment, created in Coade stone to a design by the American-born history painter, Benjamin West. These talks will explore the art and architecture of this unique space.
The King William Courtyard talk will last approximately 15 minutes and will be repeated on the hour from 11.00 to 16.00.
We regret there is no step-free access for this talk.

factsheet.heading: Jacobean Undercroft
paragraphs: Saturday 4 and Sunday 5 September, 11.00-15.00, booking essential (in person on the day)
A rare opportunity to visit the Undercroft of the Queen Anne Building, a survival from the early 1600s and the only remaining intact room from Greenwich Palace.
The Jacobean Undercroft visit will last approximately 20 minutes and will be repeated on the hour from 11.00 to 15.00.
The Undercroft is reached by a flight of steps: we regret there is no step-free access for this visit.
We request that all participants wear a face covering unless exempt.

factsheet.heading: Chapel of St Peter and St Paul
paragraphs: Bookable on the day.

The Chapel was built by English architect Thomas Ripley (1682-1758) following designs by Sir Christopher Wren, for the use of the staff and pensioners of the Royal Hospital for Seamen. In 1779 the Chapel was gutted by fire: its interior was rebuilt in a neo-classical style by James ‘Athenian’ Stuart (1713-1788). It features a large altarpiece painting by the American artist Benjamin West (1738-1820).

factsheet.heading: Smartify tour
paragraphs: Every day
The Old Royal Naval College Architecture tour on Smartify is available for a self-guided exploration of this extraordinary site.

factsheet.heading: Visitor Centre
paragraphs: Every day, 10am - 5pm, drop-in
The Visitor Centre features displays about the architecture of the site.
We request that visitors wear a face covering unless exempt.

location.address: Old Royal Naval College, Greenwich, SE10 9NN

name: Old Royal Naval College - Admiral's House, Jacobean Undercroft, talks in the grounds and Smartphone tour
